node.text:
"Today it looks like normal."

Female presenters are back on TV at a major Afghan news outlet, after briefly being taken off air as the Taliban took over Afghanistan.

Tolo News' Siyar Sirat said: "We have normal resources at the office, we have women on screen."

It comes as questions are asked over how women's rights will look under Taliban rule. 

The Taliban have given assurances that their rights will be respected according to Islamic law. 

Tap the link in our bio to find out more.

#Afghanistan #BBCNews

node.title: Female presenters return to TV in Afghanistan

node.text:
“I think I’m just shocked that it has gotten so bad, so fast.”

Photojournalist Justin Sullivan has been following California's second-largest reservoir's declining water levels since 2014.

Sullivan, who works for Getty Images, has been witnessing first-hand the climate's impact on Lake Oroville through his lens.

He says he is shocked at how fast the water is disappearing from one of California's most important water sources.

#California #LakeOroville #Environment #Water #Sustainability #BBCNews

node.title: Images show dramatic decline of California's 'life source'

node.text:
How do you handle awkward chats with your partner about money?

We spoke to three couples to understand how they handle their finances. From squabbles and lies, to what they'd do if they won the lottery, here's what they had to say.

#Money #Relationships #BBCNews

node.text:
Taliban fighters have swept across Afghanistan, taking control of towns and cities in the space of a few days.

Here is an update of what has happened over the last week.

Tap the link in our bio for the latest events in the country.

#Afghanstan #BBCNews

node.title: How the Taliban stormed across Afghanistan in 10 days

node.text:
President Joe Biden has said he stands "squarely" behind the US exit from Afghanistan as he faces withering criticism over the Taliban's lightning conquest of the war-torn country.

"How many more American lives is it worth?" said the president.

He said despite the "gut-wrenching" scenes in Kabul "there is never a good time to withdraw US forces".

On Sunday the Taliban declared victory after Afghan President Ashraf Ghani fled and his government collapsed.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more.

#JoeBiden #Afghanistan #BBCNews

node.text:
"I think every country has a role and responsibility right now."

Malala Yousafzai, who was shot in the head by Taliban gunmen in 2012, has told the BBC “countries need to open their borders to Afghan refugees”, following the fall of the country's government to the Taliban.
 
The Nobel peace laureate said she has sent a letter to Pakistan’s Prime Minister Imran Khan asking him to allow refugees, and “ensure that the refugee children and girls have access to education”.
 
#MalalaYousafzai #Afghanistan #BBCNews

node.title: Malala Yousafzai calls on countries to open borders to Afghan refugees

node.text:
Untreated sewage leads to disease around the world. Its effects are felt strongly in India, and Bangalore resident Tharun Kumar turned to cows for a solution.

He has designed and built 50 sustainable sewage plants that work in a similar way to a cow's stomach.

The amazing thing is that the system has no moving parts, so doesn't need power or people to operate it.

@bbcworldservice #Environment #Health #India #InstaGood #BBCNews

node.title: Could cows help solve the world's sewage problem?

node.text:
Witnesses say at least three people have died following desperate scenes at Kabul airport.
 
Video shows some people trying to cling on to planes as they took off.
 
With scheduled flights suspended, many foreigners and Afghans are now stranded.
 
The US and other countries have been rushing to evacuate staff and allies.
 
On Sunday the Taliban declared victory after Afghan President Ashraf Ghani fled abroad and his government collapsed.
 
The militants' return to rule brings an end to almost 20 years of a US-led coalition's presence in the country.

Tap the link in our bio for more on this story. 

#Afghanistan #Kabul #BBCNews

node.title: Chaos at Kabul airport as Afghans try to flee the Taliban.

node.text:
A 15-year-old from Sri Lanka has spent his Covid lockdown building a solar-powered tuk-tuk.

The best part is that Suntharalingam Piranawan used scraps for his homemade vehicle - and it works.

#SriLanka #BBCNews

node.text:
"Adult siblings are often the forgotten mourners and the ones that have to be strong for everyone else, so I decided I wanted to do something about that."

Triona was the youngest of three sisters. She died in hospital at 34 years old. A post-mortem examination found a blockage in her bowel as a result of scar tissue.

Her family struggled to come to terms with what happened in the aftermath of her death.

"Losing a sister or a brother, is very much like losing a part of yourself, because they are the only people that are there from the very beginning," her sister Maeveen said.

With the help of her two other sisters, they created the Sibling Grief Club.

#BBCNews

node.title: 'My sister's legacy is the Sibling Grief Club'

node.text:
"Living here is scary. We're in a hurry about what to do."

Roads out of the Afghan capital have been choked with traffic as people fearful of a Taliban takeover try to flee.

Tap the link in our bio for more live updates of the situation in Afghanistan. 

#Afghanistan #Kabul #BBCNews

node.title: People flee Kabul as Taliban enters

node.text:
“I won’t let my daughter play outside because of the shootings.”

Nakia lives a few miles from the White House in a community ravaged by gun violence. 

It’s getting worse in her neighbourhood and in many cities across the US.

Is it time for a new approach to tackle the crisis? 

#BBCCutThroughTheNoise #BBCNews

node.title: America’s deadly surge in gun violence

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Ð Ð NEWS 9 3 5 6 * 4 8 7 3 8 4 2 5 8 4 3 RR 2 4 'Godfather of Sudoku', Maki Kaji, dies aged 69'.

node.text:
Maki Kaji, the Japanese university dropout who made Sudoku a worldwide phenomenon, has died from cancer at the age of 69.

He gave the logic game its name and helped popularise it after publishing it in his puzzle magazine Nikoli in the 1980s.

Since then, the popular brain teaser - which involves placing the numbers 1 to 9 in each row, column and square of a 9 by 9 grid - has spread around the globe.

US architect Howard Garns is often credited as the creator of the modern version of the old puzzle in the 1970s, under the name Number Place - and it was this game that Kaji spotted in 1984.

"It was a very interesting puzzle, fun to solve," he said in a speech. "But the name Number Place did not hit me. I wanted to create a Japanese name."

Kaji did not trademark the game, and did not gain financially from its huge success. But he said the joy of the puzzle and of others enjoying the game were more important than any monetary reward.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the origins of the beloved game.

(📸: Getty Images)

#Sudoku #BBCNews

node.text:
Space as we’ve never seen it before! 👀

These images will transform our understanding of how galaxies evolve.

Astronomers have captured some of the most detailed images ever seen in deep space which reveal the inner workings of galaxies in unprecedented detail.

Many of the images show the role of black holes in star and planet formation and researchers say that the pictures will transform our understanding of how galaxies evolve.

The scientists, led by Dr Leah Moarabito from Durham University linked over 70,000 small antennae to improve the resolution of radio images which show light that originated when the Universe was only 2.6 billion years old.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the ultra HD images.

#Astronomy #Space #BBCNews

node.text:
"Today it looks like normal."

Female presenters are back on TV at a major Afghan news outlet, after briefly being taken off air as the Taliban took over Afghanistan.

Tolo News' Siyar Sirat said: "We have normal resources at the office, we have women on screen."

It comes as questions are asked over how women's rights will look under Taliban rule. 

The Taliban have given assurances that their rights will be respected according to Islamic law. 

Tap the link in our bio to find out more.

#Afghanistan #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on August 17, 2021. May be an image of fire and outdoors.

node.text:
Israeli firefighters are battling a massive wildfire west of Jerusalem that has burned 2,000 hectares (5,000 acres) of forest over the past three days.

The blaze appeared to have been brought under control on Sunday night but strong winds and low humidity caused it to regain intensity.

Authorities were forced to evacuate about 2,000 residents of nearby towns and villages as a precaution.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more. 

#Israel #BBCNews

node.text:
The Taliban have taken control of Afghanistan. But who are they and how did they manage to take power so quickly?

The Taliban are an Islamist group who controlled Afghanistan from 1996-2001 when they were ousted by a military invasion led by the USA. 

The US and allies invaded as they said the Taliban had been sheltering al-Queda before and after the 9/11 terror attack. 

Before 2001 the Taliban imposed strict Sharia law requiring women to be fully covered when in public and enforcing their laws by public executions and amputations. 

They say that they will govern differently this time but many are still worried life will return to how it was before 2001. 

Click on the link in our bio for more about who the Taliban are. 

(📷 Getty)

#BBCNews #Afghanistan #Taliban

node.text:
“I think I’m just shocked that it has gotten so bad, so fast.”

Photojournalist Justin Sullivan has been following California's second-largest reservoir's declining water levels since 2014.

Sullivan, who works for Getty Images, has been witnessing first-hand the climate's impact on Lake Oroville through his lens.

He says he is shocked at how fast the water is disappearing from one of California's most important water sources.

#California #LakeOroville #Environment #Water #Sustainability #BBCNews

node.text:
How do you handle awkward chats with your partner about money?

We spoke to three couples to understand how they handle their finances. From squabbles and lies, to what they'd do if they won the lottery, here's what they had to say.

#Money #Relationships #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'BBCNES BBC NEWS New Zealand enters lockdown over one Covid case'.

node.text:
New Zealand is going into a snap lockdown after a man tested positive for coronavirus – the first case in the country in six months.

Auckland, where the case was detected, will be in lockdown for a week, while the rest of the country will be in lockdown for three days.

Authorities say they are working on the assumption that the new case was the Delta variant.

"I want to assure New Zealand that we have planned for this eventuality. Going hard and early has worked for us before," Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said.

Tap a link in our bio to read more about the situation in New Zealand.

(📷 Getty Images)

#NewZealand #Covid #Covid_19 #Coronavirus #BBCNews

node.text:
Taliban fighters have swept across Afghanistan, taking control of towns and cities in the space of a few days.

Here is an update of what has happened over the last week.

Tap the link in our bio for the latest events in the country.

#Afghanstan #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on August 16, 2021. May be an image of 4 people, crowd and indoor.

node.text:
A striking image has gone viral on social media - showing hundreds of people crowded on a US Air Force C-17 aircraft as it left Kabul for Qatar on Sunday.

Scores of panicked Afghans, who had already been cleared to leave the country, managed to pull themselves onto the aircraft’s half-open ramp. Instead of forcing them off, the crew decided to take off.

According to Defense One, a site which obtained the image from the military, around 640 people were on board - far more than its listed capacity.

The picture is in stark contrast to the chaotic scenes just a day later - when thousands of people crowded Kabul’s airport and had difficulty fleeing the country. Planes were temporarily grounded, and US forces reportedly shot dead two armed men.

Tap the link in our bio for more live updates.

(📸: Defense One)

#Afghanistan #Kabul #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on August 16, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and text.

node.text:
Women in Afghanistan are fearing for their future after the Taliban gained control of the country at an alarming speed.

Already, there was a noticeable difference in the country’s main TV channels - the disappearance of some female presenters from the screen, according to checks by BBC Monitoring. 

Meanwhile, women like Ms Zeb Hanifa (not her real name), who has worked as a PR consultant and writer, is worried she may no longer be able to work.

“I am broken,” she told the BBC. “There are so many young women like me - our dreams are shattered.”

The Taliban have said that all sections of the society will have civil freedoms in their rule, but analysts say it's too early to trust such promises. 

In the 1990s, life under the Taliban saw women forced to wear the all-covering burqa, education restricted for girls over 10 and brutal punishments brought in, including public executions.

Tap the link in our bio for more live updates.

(📸: Getty Images)

#Afghanistan #Kabul #Women #BBCNews

node.text:
President Joe Biden has said he stands "squarely" behind the US exit from Afghanistan as he faces withering criticism over the Taliban's lightning conquest of the war-torn country.

"How many more American lives is it worth?" said the president.

He said despite the "gut-wrenching" scenes in Kabul "there is never a good time to withdraw US forces".

On Sunday the Taliban declared victory after Afghan President Ashraf Ghani fled and his government collapsed.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more.
